titleStmt.title: Instability Analysis and Robust Adaptive Control of Robotic Manipulators

analytic.title: Instability Analysis and Robust Adaptive Control of Robotic Manipulators

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: 38 1 tions for simple moves in an optimal manner. This permits them to be performed in minimum time. The results obtained in this study suggest that substantial increases in system productivity can be achieved by the use of the method proposed in this communication. This method is applicable to industrial tasks where manipulators must go to a number of positions, stopping at each point. This problem is structured into the form of the well-known traveling salesman problem, and it is solved by an exact tour-building type of algorithm based on the branch-and-bound technique. The approach can also be applied to problems in which some ordering of manipulator motions is dictated by a task, problem which generally cannot be treated as a TSP.

It was also shown that nonoptimal move times, obtained from measurement or simulations, can be used with the optimal tour building technique to obtain improved, although suboptimal, task times. Ideally, these should be the optimal times obtained using the methods discussed above for simple motions. However, if these approaches are not used, dynamic simulations and experimental timings may be substituted. Dynamic simulations and experimental timings should result in improved overall task performance over ad hoc task planning, but the results will be suboptimal.

Additionally, it was shown that a kinematic inversion approach can be used to structure manipulator tasks and their work environments, so that the tasks can be completed in minimum time. An approximate method for optimizing tasks for more than one manipulator has also been discussed. Exact solutions for this problem do not appear feasible with this approach; additional research is clearly needed in this area.

This algorithm was implemented in Fortran on a relatively small Digital Equipment Corporation PDP-1 1/44 minicomputer. The optimal motions for the simple moves used to build the overall motion were obtained from a computer-aided design (CAD) software package, called OPTARM, run on a Micro Vax II. Computation time is not critical since the method is clearly an off-line task planning tool. Nonetheless, the computation times required by this approach were quite reasonable, even for these minicomputer systems. Obtaining the individual move times may require substantial effort for very large problems. A method to reduce this effort is suggested in this communication. In any event, the approach is probably best suited for use in a computer-aided design environment with solid modeling and dynamic simulation capabilities.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: The dynamic control of the multi-link robotic manipulator has intrigued many control systems researchers. The system is characterized by many nonlinearities and strong coupling between the individual links of the manipulator chain. Precise trajectory control will be required in many of the envisioned applications of manipulators (e.g., machining, welding, complex assembly). An attractive alternative to conventional fixed controllers, which may exhibit undesirable overshoot behavior when the plant parameters are unknown or are changed, is adaptive control. By adding provisions to adapt to the dynamic operating environment (e.g., load/tool changes, workpiece variations) as well as to simply identify other unknown and possibly time-varying parameters of the robotic plant on-line, better performance and productivity might be achieved.

The wealth of knowledge of adaptive control developed within the last decade or so has inspired many attempts to apply adaptive control theory to the robotic manipulator. A recent survey [l] indicates the breadth of the approaches taken. One of the early applications of adaptive control to the manipulator problem came from Horowitz and Tomizuka [2] in 1980. Their scheme assumed the plant inertia to be time-invariant and assumed the gravitylfriction torques to be known. Later methods that assumed time-invariance include [3] and [4]. Another pioneering attempt at the adaptive manipulator control problem was given in Dubowsky and DesForges [5] in 1979. In [ 5 ] , the model was linearized with the higher order terms discarded. Subsequently, many other researchers [6]-[ 101 have considered controlling a linear perturbational/variational model by assuming the full nonlinear model to be following a nominal trajectory due to some nominal control. Discrete-time adaptive manipulator control algorithms were presented by Tomizuka and Horowitz [I 11,and Elliot et al. [12]. In addition to other assumptions, the discrete-time result still did not account for the effects of discretizing a nonlinear plant model.

The important original work in the results above applied the adaptive control theory concurrently being developed for linear timeinvariant systems by making approximations and assumptions about the nonlinear manipulator plant. The nonlinearities and cross couplings between links were ignored, assumed to be sufficiently small, linearized with first-order approximations, or even assumed to be constant. Many of these arguments break down immediately as the manipulator is moved faster or as smaller gear ratios for the link actuators are employed. For the large gear ratios typical of presentday production manipulators, the link dynamics are dominated by the actuator dynamics; so the plant largely appears to the controller as a set of decoupled LTI systems. Since the trend is toward hightechnology direct-drive actuators, the lack of high gear ratios and increasing demand for high-speed operation implies that the control system will have to account for the nonlinear link dynamics which will be dominant.

In fact, adaptive control algorithms have been developed which assume the full nonlinear manipulator model in the analysis. These results belong to one of two general categories: adaptive "high-gain'' cancellation of the nonlinearities and "adaptive computed torque. " Of the first type, the notable contributions include Nicosia and Tomei [13], Balestrino,DeMaria,and Sciavicco [14], Singh [15], and Lim and Eslami [16]. These adaptive schemes are similar in that they utilize tracking error feedback (position and rate errors) with an adaptive gain that grows until it is large enough to cancel the nonlinearities. An unanswered question in these schemes is how to select certain parameters and gains within the adaptation loop which depend upon the closed-loop plant. Another major drawback with many of these schemes is that the control law may chatter and excite the unmodeled dynamics; and robustness to these effects has not been established. The chattering can be moderated through the use of a dead zone in the control law and adaptation as shown by Slotine in [ 171. For the dead-zone scheme, boundedness of closed-loop signals can still be obtained with bounded disturbances; but a nonzero steadystate error bound is inevitable even without disturbances. Robustness to unmodeled dynamics has not been shown either.

The second category of existing adaptive controller designs with full nonlinear manipulator plant models utilize the computed torque control law with some additional terms to provide for stability. Contributions in this area include Craig,Hsu,and Sastry [18], Middleton and Goodwin [19], Slotine and Li [20], Sadegh and Horowitz [21], and Bayard and Wen [22]. Craig, Hsu, and Sastry's controller requires measurements of link angle acceleration as well as link angle positjon and rate. Middleton and Goodwin remove the dependence on 0 by using filtered signals in the adaptation loop. The robustness of these adaptive computed torque schemes with respect to plant uncertainties such as unmodeled dynamics, parameter variations, etc., has not been analyzed.

The work towards applying adaptive control to the robotic manipulator has progressed from early attempts at applying standard adaptive control schemes, originally designed for linear time-invariant plants, to simplified or approximate models to later attempts with more advanced techniques based on the full nonlinear manipulator model. The deficiencies alluded to in the above paragraphs indicate that for most of the results so far, the stability analyses are incomplete since they do not account for modeling errors, especially unmodeled dynamics. Likewise, little or no analysis has been performed for the case of time-varying plant parameters with adaptive manipulator control.

The objective considered here for the adaptive control of the rigidlink manipulator is to track a bounded, possibly high-speed, trajectory, including angular positions, rates, and accelerations, in the presence of uncertainty about the manipulator parameters and more importantly the load parameters. These parameters can be timevarying due to smooth variations (e.g., mechanical wear or aging) or instantaneous changes (e.g., dropping the load). Another critical requirement is that the adaptive scheme be robust in the presence of disturbances, plant parameter variations, and unmodeled dynamices.

div.head: INSTABILITY ANALYSIS
div.p: In this section the approach of [23] is used to show via example how instability can arise in an existing adaptive control scheme. For simplicity, consider a single-link manipulator with no actuator dynamics and no gravity terms

where 0 is the link angle, 7 is the input torque, m( = 1) is the un-known link mass, and d(t) is a bounded input disturbance. Furthermore, assume that dl and d2 represent bounded disturbances on the measurements of O(t) and e(t), respectively. Here we also assume the regulation case where the desired link angle position, rate, and acceleration are all zero.
As an example, consider the recent result of Slotine and Li [20]. The adaptive controller in this case, applied to ( S ) , is given by
Using the positive-definite function

div.p: and nothing can be concluded about the stability of the parameter estimate k(t) since s(t) does not converge to zero for nonzero disturbances. As a matter of fact, instability can be shown for

This type of instability may have even more catastrophic effects when unmodeled dynamics are also present since parameter drift may excite the unmodeled dynamics as shown in [23] for linear controller structures.

The point to be made here is not whether (12) and (13) represent realistic disturbances or not but rather that robustness has not been guaranteed by this controller design; and a counterexample has easily been found that has disproved stability implying that a large class of disturbances exist which would cause similar instability. Instability can also be demonstrated for the adaptive manipulator controller given by Craig,Hsu,and Sastry in [18].

div.head: v . ROBUST ADAPTIVE CONTROL WITH TIME-VARYING PLANT PARAMETERS
div.p: One of the principal reasons for applying adaptive control to the robotic manipulator is that the parameter vector can change during the on-line operation of the manipulator. If the parameter vector were in fact constant, one could utilize off-line identification techniques to obtain the parameters and consequently use a much simpler fixed controller.

We now consider the case when the unknown plant parameter As before, consider the manipulator model in ( 16)-( 18) complete with bounded disturbance and unmodeled dynamics, now with M * replaced by M * ( t ) , The control law ( 19) and adaptive law in ( 24) remain the same. The error equations for the close$loop are still given by (31, (4), (22), and ( 24) but now M ( t ) # M ( t ) due to the parameter variations. As a result of ( 35)

In addition to the remarks following Theorem 1, the following comments are made.

Remark 5: As with the time-invariant plant parameter case, global stability is obtained without unmodeled dynamics ( p = 0). Remark 6: We make no requirement on the rate of plant parameter variations, other than an implicit requirement that m l , m2 < < l/p. However, a large m l or m2 results in a large residual error set bound. For no jump parameter changes (m2 = 0), we see that the tracking performance approaches that of the constant plant parameter case as the speed of the parameter variations decreases. Likewise, for a finite number of jump parameter changes, we see that the mean of the tracking errors depends only upon the smooth parameter variation speed. Without the o-modification and even without modeling errors, stability has not been previously established with plant parameter variations/jumps. VI. CONCLUSION In this communication, the robustness of adaptive manipulator control was investigated. A simple example demonstrated the nonrobustness of a recent adaptive result to bounded disturbances. A new robust adaptive controller was then analyzed to show the existence of a "large" region of attraction from which all signals remain bounded. The mean of the tracking error is shown t o be proportional to the bound on the disturbances, the bounds on the speed of the smooth plant parameter variations and size of the jump plant parameter changes, and the strength of the unmodeled dynamics. T h e parameters are not required to be slowly varying in order t o guarantee boundedness; but tracking performance may b e affected by fast variations. Furthermore, for j u m p parameter changes, the minimum time between jumps is assumed to be bounded from below. In the analysis herein, the designer is not forced to select controller parameters that depend directly upon the particular plant dynamics in order to maintain stability. The only U priori knowledge necessary is an upper bound on the magnitude of the unknown parameter vector; and this information is not required to show boundedness of all closed-loop signals. Robustness is obtained through the adaptation strucure; and "persistently exciting" signals are not required for stability or robustness.

figure.figDesc: If os were fixed to a nonzero value, then boundedness can be shown but a steadystate error bound would result even without modeling errors, as is the case with other types of robustness modifications [27] such as a dead zone in the adaptive law. If the condition that MO > 11 M * 11 is not met, uniform boundedness is still guaranteed even with unmodeled dynamics and bounded disturbances[28] ; but convergence of the tracking errors is to a larger residual error set containing an additional 11 M * 11 term in the bound. Without us instability can occur as shown in the previous section. Another implicit requirement is that 11 Od 11, 11 Od 11, 11 Or) 11, 11 r 11, 11 A 11, and 11 P 11 < < 1/p. The implication is that high-gain feedback, fast adaptation, and excessive plant excitation in the high-frequency range result in the excitation of the unmodeled dynamics and could cause instability. This point is a possible argument against the use of high-gain feedback to cancel the known nonlinearities.
